newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia rights body urges military care.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia rights body urges military care.

text.p: Indonesia's human rights commission has urged the nation's powerful armed forces to carefully resolve tensions that sparked recent riots, Antara news agency reported on Sunday.
Riots in several areas of Indonesia have rocked the multi-ethnic country since late last year and the military has been criticised for its handling of the disturbances.

"ABRI (armed forces) must solve the riots wisely and the government must solve the problems honestly, otherwise they will continue to happen," Antara quoted Baharuddin Lopa, secretary-general of the National Commission of Human Rights, as saying on Saturday.
Lopa, speaking to reporters before attending a seminar, said unfair settlement of the riots would only prompt people to oppose the government and its security apparatuses.
Lopa also said the May 29 general elections should be carried out in an honest way to avoid unrest which could disrupt the polls. Antara gave no further details.

On Wednesday, at least three government offices, 11 vehicles and dozens of homes were damaged and 14 people were injured in Wonosobo, Central Java, in clashes between supporters of the Moslem-based United Development Party (PPP) and the ruling Golkar party, newspapers have said.
Five people had been questioned after the riots.
Wonosobo was one of several towns in Central Java hit by violence in the past two weeks, sparked by clashes between PPP and Golkar supporters.

Riots broke out in the coastal town of Pekalongan, a PPP stronghold, two weeks ago after reports that a popular folk singer who has campaigned for the PPP in the past would be a Golkar candidate in the May 29 general elections.
Pekalongan's riot was the first violent disturbance in Java since a mob attacked Chinese homes and businesses, Christian churches and Buddhist temples in Tasikmalaya town in West Java in January.
Four people died in those riots, sparked by police brutality against a Moslem teacher.
At least 200 people died in clashes between local Dayaks and immigrant Madurese in West Kalimantan province on Borneo island which started in December and lasted through February.
Only three political parties -- the PPP, Golkar and the Indonesian Democratic Party (PDI) -- are allowed to contest Indonesia's general elections.
